fields.description:
BBL Asset Management, with Khon Thai Foundation and ChangeFusion Institute, have launched the ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ mutual fund – Thailand’s first ESGC mutual fund.


Mrs Voravan Tarapoom, CEO of BBL Asset Management Co., Ltd. (BBLAM), said that BBLAM has teamed with Khon Thai Foundation and ChangeFusion Institute to create a new mutual fund called ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ or BKIND. This fund is Thailand’s first ESGC fund which allows investors to contribute to the society and environment through their investment.


The ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ mutual fund aims to invest its investors’ money only in companies that have taken part in four aspects of social responsibilities, which are Environment, Society, Good Governance, and Anti-Corruption. This ‘ESGC’ consideration is the fund’s criteria for stock selection along with fundamental analysis, under an underlying concept that profitable and sustainable companies are those who operate for the genuine betterment of Thai society. The ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ fund brings this concept into practice in order to seek sustainable return on investment in a long term. It invests in listed companies in The Stock Exchange of Thailand, the MAI, and other secondary markets of The Stock Exchange of Thailand.


‘Apart from being the first mutual fund that invests in companies that met ESGC criteria, the “Khon Thai Jai Dee” fund is also the first fund that gives 40% of its management fee, equivalent to 0.8% of the total asset value, to the support of or the investment in various public benefit projects. This makes every baht of investors’ money a contribution to efforts to sustainably improve Thai society. The selection of public benefit projects will be conducted by an appropriate committee. Investors who take part in the “Khon Thai Jai Dee” fund will therefore have a chance to be givers to the society. This fund bring together people who like to give by using a mechanism of mutual fund. It is an innovation of investment instrument, where investors both take profit opportunities and give to the society at the same time.’, Mrs Voravan said.


This mutual fund is positioned as a choice for investors who favour a long-term investment approach in good-performance companies that have shown their care for the four aspects of social responsibilities (ESGC) and would like every baht of their investment to be a contribution to the creation of the better Thai society. It also suits investors who can accept short-term fluctuation of the price of investment units, as this being an equity fund with an aim for large return in a long-term time span. The fund will moreover attract juristic persons or institutional investors who would like to see their investment fund being used to support projects that create sustainable benefits to Thai society.


Mr Vichien Phongsathorn, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Khon Thai Foundation, describes the reason for which Khon Thai Foundation has taken part in the development of and also the investment in the ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ fund, that the foundation would like to see every parts of Thai society, including investors, united to solve social problems. This endeavour to reform the country is a grand mission which necessitates participation and contribution not just from the government but from all sectors in order to succeed. The capital market sector can surely help; one can consider if only 1% of the 14 trillion baht yearly investment in Thai listed companies can be channelled to social investment. This 1% investment for social good will in turn allows the remaining 99% traditional investment to grow sustainably.


With this reason, Khon Thai Foundation and ChangeFusion Institute hence brought the idea to BBL Asset Management. We then worked together to convert the aforementioned principle into a mechanism embedded in the ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ mutual fund. This mechanism aims to create a two-fold benefit. One is to allow investors to support companies that exhibit good corporate governance practice according to the world-wide recognised ESG criteria. This fund added the ‘C’ which is a dedicated Anti-Corruption criterion. The second-fold benefit is a mechanism which routinely directs 0.8% of investors’ money (through 40% separation of the fund’s management fee) to support selected public benefit projects in different segments which aim to solve societal problems and create a better society.


‘In the near future, Khon Thai Foundation intends to develop other types of social investment fund, and at the same time further improve the ESGC criteria with The Stock Exchange of Thailand, The Securities and Exchange Commission, and Thai Institute of Directors, to establish the ESGC criteria as the Thailand’s Socially Responsible Investment (SRI) standard which every organisations can utilise.’, Mr Vichien said.


Mr Sunit Shrestha, Director of ChangeFusion Institute, Foundation for Thailand Rural Reconstruction Movement Under Royal Patronage, elaborates upon the selection criteria of public benefit projects that are eligible for receiving support from the fund’s management fee; they should be projects that aim to create a new future of Thai society working on current and important social issues, the social impact generated must be tangible and measurable, projects should be able to operate sustainably and their results duplicable or expandable, and they should relate with important reform issues such as education, inequality reduction especially in the agricultural sector, anti-corruption, and environmental preservation and restoration.


Eligible projects for public benefit should also have clear operation plans. They should be run by creditable organisations, groups, or individuals. The selection process starts with a working group consists of ChangeFusion Institute and Khon Thai Foundation preparing information of eligible projects, then proposes the list to the project selection committee. This committee consists of reputable and experience individuals known to be familiar with societal problems in Thailand and have publicly-recognised visions to solve those problems. They are an economist, Mr Veerathai Santiprabhob; a Board Member of the Thai Social Enterprise Office, Mrs Wiwan Tharahirunchote; the Director of Ashoka Thailand, Mrs Sinee Chakthranont; a Board Member of BBL Asset Management, Mr Chone Sophonpanich; the CEO of BBL Asset Management, Mrs Voravan Tarapoom; the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Khon Thai Foundation, Mr Vichien Phongsathorn; and the Director of ChangeFusion Institute, Mr Sunit Shrestha.


Mr Sunit further explains that the project selection committee will meet to select projects that will receive support, altogether with amounts and conditions of support, then to comply with the law and regulations, the final list will be approved and signed off by the disbursement committee. The money will be deposited at a ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ project account hold by Yuwapat Foundation, from where the money will be disbursed to each project. The working team will continually assess the progress of each project and make quarterly report to be sent to the fund’s investors.


The ‘Khon Thai Jai Dee’ mutual fund, or BKIND, will make an Initial Public Offering (IPO) during 20-28 October 2014 at 10 baht per unit. 1,000 baht is the minimum purchasing amount and the minimum incremental amount. The registered fund’s value is specified at 5,000 million baht. Interested investors can inquire for more information at BBL Asset Management, tel. 0 2674 6488 #8, or visit www.bblam.co.th, any Bangkok Bank branches nationwide, Bualuang Phone 1333, or www.bangkokbank.com


Disclaimer: Investment is not risk-free. Investors should study relevant information before making investment decision.

fields.description:
Register now...

The 2014 programme is particularly exciting as this is the first time an Asian country has hosted Social Enterprise World Forum (SEWF).  

The Work Together Foundation (WT) is honoured to be hosting the forum and will use the SEWF as a platform to showcase the work and impact social entrepreneurs in Korea are making.

It is expected that 80% of the delegates at SEWF 2014 will be from Asian countries where social enterprise has taken hold and is addressing significant social economic and environmental issues.  In recent years Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan, Myanmar, Bangladesh and Singapore have accelerated their social enterprise development.

Key themes during the SEWF conference will include social enterprise as an employability solution, social care and health innovations in social enterprise, as well as conference tracks dealing with social investment, social innovation, education and creating supportive social enterprise ecosystems.     

For further information or to book your place now, visit www.sewf2014.org/en/

SEUK's CEO, Peter Holbrook, is Chair of the SEWF and one of global team behind this year's event.
fields.title: Social Enterprise World Forum
fields.summary: The 2014 programme is particularly exciting as this is the first time an Asian country has hosted Social Enterprise World Forum (SEWF).

fields.description:
The 2nd annual Nexus Thailand Youth Summit will take place from October 31-November 2, 2014 in Bangkok. The intimate summit-retreat will bring together young philanthropists and social leaders to create opportunities for sharing, learning, inspiration and collaboration on critical issues that affect Thailand and the region.

Apply Now

If you have any questions, contact us at thailand@nexusyouthsummit.org

Go here for the 2013 Nexus Thailand Youth Summit
fields.title: Nexus Thailand Youth Summit 2014
fields.summary: The intimate summit-retreat will bring together young philanthropists and social leaders to create opportunities for sharing, learning, inspiration and collaboration on critical issues that affect Thailand and the region.

fields.description:
Save the date: 20 – 23 April 2015

Venue: National University of Singapore, UTown

Registration for the 2015 AVPN Conference will open for members in December 2014. Please look out for notification on registration and updates on speakers and programme at the official website:www.avpn2015.com

For more information on sponsorship, partnership opportunities, please contactconference2015@avpn.asia We also welcome volunteer queries.

 

To find out more about our past year’s conference, visit:

www.avpn2014.com

The 2014 AVPN Conference was held over 3 days and saw almost 400 speakers and delegates, with additional member activities atop our plenaries, breakouts, workshops and investment pitching!

www.avpn2013.com

The inaugural AVPN Conference in 2013 received 340 delegates from 31 countries even as an invite-only event for the social investing community. The buzz and excitement generated from the event heralded more great things to come for the space and market.

 

Lead Partner
fields.title: AVPN Conference 2015
fields.summary: The 2014 AVPN Conference was held over 3 days and saw almost 400 speakers and delegates, with additional member activities atop our plenaries, breakouts, workshops and investment pitching! Registration for the 2015 AVPN Conference will open

fields.description:
Set up in 2005, Ziqitza, an emergency ambulance operator, brings affordable healthcare to some of India’s poorest people. The social enterprise operates around 1,250 ambulances across 17 Indian states. By its own calculations, its cross-subsidised model has helped 3.2 million people get to hospital, saving thousands of lives in the process.

This is just one of a growing number of social enterprises using innovative strategies to give India’s under-served poor access to quality healthcare. Other notable examples include Narayana Hrudayalaya hospitals and the eye care providers L V Prasad Eye Institute and Aravind Eye Care System.

India spends 4% of its GDP on health (less than half that of the UK), meaning government-run hospitals and clinics are invariably over-stretched and under-resourced. Those who can afford it, go private while the vast majority of India’s 1.2 billion people rely on the state.

The idea of using market-based solutions to help provide affordable healthcare to the poor makes “perfect sense”, according to Ajit Mahadevan, India country director for the impact investment fund Acumen. Over the last decade, the US investor has ploughed around $16m into 10 pro-poor healthcare providers across the country.

“There are willing customers out there for low-cost, quality health services, but they are not getting serviced”, says Mahadevan, who insists that Acumen’s goal is not to make a “fat return” but to reinvest any returns in a revolving fund for other social enterprises.

He accepts that some may feel uncomfortable about the idea of making money from the poor – a criticism that India’s microfinance sector has faced. But as long as the services and products remain affordable and high quality, he sees no problem. Treating patients as “valued customers” gives them dignity too, he argues. What’s more it offers the poor the rare opportunity to hold their health provider to account.

Business viability

When it comes to serving the poor, the returns are invariably too low or the effort too high to interest mainstream businesses. Hence the need for a values-based approach that sees revenue generation as a means, not an end, says Ziqitza’s co-founder and chief executive, Sweta Mangal.

“Private ambulance services that are out-and-out commercial will only provide a service to you if you are willing to pay for it. But my objective as a social enterprise is first to save a life and second to be [financially] sustainable.”

Tiered pricing is one way to achieve such economic sustainability. By charging rich patients more, health service providers can generate cross-subsidies for the poor. Ziqitza’s method of distinguishing between the two is whether they ask to go to a private or government hospital: crude perhaps, but an accurate benchmark of relative income for the most part.

Public-private partnerships present a second possible option. Ziqitza has a contract to deliver ambulance services for the states of Bihar, Orissa and Punjab and generates extra revenue from corporate advertising on the sides of its vehicles.

Keeping costs low offers another obvious route to economic viability. Asian Health Alliance (AHA), a low-cost provider of diagnostic services in the state of Karnataka, benefits from lower business rates and real estate costs because it operates primarily in semi-urban and rural areas. It also runs courier services, avoiding the cost of expensive middlemen by picking up samples itself. AHA’s costs are 25-30% lower than the sector’s larger players – savings that it can use to offer cheaper services.

Achieving scale

It’s not all sacrifice, however. Pro-poor health companies tap into new markets that mainstream operators have ignored. “Everyone wants to go to a bigger market to do business”, says Mohapatra. “But the rural market is equally big, but it’s very widely distributed so it takes a lot more effort.” AHA currently services 150 patients per day, all of them earning less than $2.50 per day. It hopes to reach 1,000 patients within two years.

The biggest challenge for social enterprises in India’s healthcare sector is scale. With scale comes wider social impact and greater aggregated revenues (a critical factor if your charges are kept intentionally low to remain affordable). And helping social enterprises scale is where Acumen and similar impact investors, such as Intellecap and Unitus Seed Fund, come in.

Back in 2007, Ziqitza was able to expand the ambulance fleet from 10 to 100 thanks to a $1.5m investment from Acumen. The fund has since invested a further $1.2m. Likewise, a $750,000 investment in AHA last year means the company can now take on new staff and expand its network of collection centres.

Acumen’s Mahadevan insists it’s not just cash that impact investors bring to the table. “Of course, they (social enterprises) need money”, he says. “But there’s a big difference between those who just bring money and those who bring advice and connections too.”

Source: http://www.theguardian.com
fields.title: [test] Pay for your ambulance? How India's poorest are gaining access to he
fields.summary: While some may feel uncomfortable making money from the poor, social enterprise and emergency ambulance operator Ziqitza, estimates it has saved thousands of lives
